title: How to Host a Bridal Shower Tea Party

parts.name: Determining the Guest List and the Venue

steps.headline: Make the guest list.
steps.description: List all of the guests you plan to invite, as well as their plus ones. Decide if you are inviting children to the party as well, or adults only. Ask the bride’s friends or family to help you draw up the guest list. Bridal shower guest lists usually include the bride’s closest friends and family, as well as the groom’s friends or family. Keep in mind you do not need to invite everyone on the wedding guest list to the bridal shower. Just make sure everyone invited to the bridal shower is also invited to the wedding. You may have a cap on how many people you can host at the bridal shower. Most bridal showers have around 30 people for a larger party and as small as 10-15 people for a more intimate party.

steps.headline: Decide if you are going to host the party at your home.
steps.description: If the guest list is small, you may host the party at your home. Usually parties no bigger than 10-20 people are ideal as long as you have a larger home for hosting. If you are hosting the party in your home, you may need to move furniture around or put items away to make space for your guests. Try walking through your home to see how easy it is for others to move around. Designate a few small tables for food and drinks, and set up chairs for guests to sit. If you have a larger guest list, such as 30 people or more, you may decide to host the bridal shower at a venue other than your home. You may look into renting a community hall or reserving tables at a local restaurant, especially if it has a garden.

steps.headline: Pick an indoor or outdoor setting.
steps.description: Go for an outdoor setting, such as your garden or backyard, if you know the weather is going to be warm and pleasant for the party date. If you are worried about the weather, you may host the party indoors in your home, or at another indoor venue. You can also have a plan B, where you move the party indoors if the weather isn’t great on the day of the party.

steps.headline: Offer a selection of teas.
steps.description: Have a variety of teas on hand, such as peppermint, chamomile, and classics like Earl Grey and English Breakfast. Keep hot water in a kettle or thermos so your guests can prepare their own tea. Make sure you also have milk, half and half, and sugar cubes or packaged sugar on hand. You can also make a iced tea in a pitcher, such as lavender or chamomile tea over ice.

steps.headline: Prepare cocktails.
steps.description: If you want to serve alcohol at the bridal shower, try preparing a cocktail with prosecco for a bubbly drink. Or you can make the bride’s favorite drink at the party and serve it to your guests. You can also prepare a fruit punch for the party and make it alcoholic by adding your favorite alcohol to the punch.

steps.headline: Make tea sandwiches.
steps.description: Tea sandwiches are a must at a tea party. Prepare cucumber tea sandwiches with cucumber, butter, and bread. You can also make egg salad sandwiches, smoked salmon sandwiches, and avocado shrimp sandwiches. Invite friends of bride over for a tea sandwich making session at your home the day before the party, or a few hours before the party. You can also hire a caterer to make the tea sandwiches for the party if you’d prefer.

steps.headline: Prepare deviled eggs.
steps.description: Deviled eggs are another classic finger food for a tea party. Make classic deviled eggs or put a southern twist on them with pickles and pimento. You can also make bacon and guacamole deviled eggs or for a fancier option, deviled egg canapes.

steps.headline: Make scones, shortbread, and other desserts.
steps.description: Prepare a platter of homemade scones to serve to your guests. You can also make shortbread rounds, and decorate them with the bride’s name or other designs if you’re feeling extra crafty. Other desserts like cake slices, cheesecake bars, and strawberries dipped in chocolate are also great for a tea party. Just make sure all the desserts are easy for your guests to pick up and hold with their fingers.

steps.headline: Include sides like clotted cream, jam, honey, and butter.
steps.description: Put out sides to accompany the scones and shortbread you are serving your guests. Go for locally sourced honey and jam. Bring the butter to room temperature or warm it up slightly so it is easy for your guests to spread.

steps.headline: Make your own themed invitations.
steps.description: Use a soft color scheme to match the theme, such as pale pink, blue, or yellow. Mount the invitations on cardstock and write them by hand. You can also type up the invitations if you have a lot to send out. Include images that the bride likes on the invitations, such as an animal or item she likes. You can also put images that suit the theme, such as a tea cup, a bridal veil, or a garden scene.

steps.headline: Order themed invitations online or at a store.
steps.description: If you’d prefer to get the invitations done by a professional, order them through an online store or in person at a local design store. Make sure you order the invitations several weeks in advance of the party date so you can send them out in time. You can also set up e-invites, where a personalized invitation is sent out to your guests by email.

steps.headline: Note the date, time, and location of the party.
steps.description:
Follow tea party protocol and have the party at the traditional tea time, 4 pm. Or, be modern and host the party at noon or 1 pm so it is still an afternoon affair. Be detailed about the exact time and date of the party, as well as the full address of the venue in the invitation. For example, you may write: “Join us for a tea party to celebrate the bride-to-be at 1 pm on Saturday, September 10th, 2017. The party will be in the backyard garden at 1234 Smith Street SW.”
Most bridal showers are a surprise for the bride. You may specify this in the invitation so no one ruins the surprise.

steps.headline: Include a note about a dress code, if desired.
steps.description: If you want your guests to dress up for the tea party in their finest fancy attire, specify this in the invitation. You may suggest that guests dress in party frocks, pearls, and fancy hats to get into the theme. Or you may recommend guests show up in “fancy outfits” and let them use their imaginations. For example, you may note in the invitation: “Dress in your fanciest frock, pearls, and pretty hats, if you desire. Dressing up is recommended, but of course, not mandatory.”

steps.headline: Send out invitations at least two weeks before the party date.
steps.description: Give your guests ample time to reserve the day for the party. In the invitations, you can also ask guests to RSVP by a certain date so you know who is coming to the tea party.

steps.headline: Hang a welcome banner.
steps.description: Make a welcome banner out of fabric or paper to hang over the doorway or over the food and drinks table. You can even spell out the bride’s name on the banner. You can also buy a welcome banner for the party at your local craft store or online.

steps.headline: Include a food and drinks table.
steps.description: Designate a table in the center of the venue for food and drinks. Put finger foods on tiered platters or plates. Set out tea bags, hot water, sugar, and milk on the table. To make the table extra fancy, put a tablecloth on it as well as cloth napkins.

steps.headline: Have a gifts table.
steps.description: It is tradition for guests to bring small gifts for the bride to the bridal shower. Make sure you have a table or area set aside for gifts. Put a sign up that says “gifts” so guests know where to put them.

steps.headline: Set out fresh flower arrangements.
steps.description: Fresh flowers add an extra level of detail to a tea party. Order fresh flowers from a local florist in the bride’s favorite colors, or in her wedding colors. Put them all over the venue in vases.

steps.headline: Have a variety of tea cups, saucers, and utensils.
steps.description: Mix and match tea cups for a more funky set up. Or have matching sets of tea cups and saucers for your guests to use. Make sure you include spoons, forks, and serving plates as well. Look for utensils made of silver or copper for a tea party look. You can also get serving plates that have floral designs for a more festive party feel.

steps.headline: Decorate the venue beforehand.
steps.description: Ask friends or family members to help you set up the party the day before, or a few hours before. This way, you are not scrambling to decorate the venue and you can feel organized for when your guests arrive. You may designate tasks to different people to ensure the party is set up quickly and correctly. For example, you may have one person organize the fresh flower arrangements and another person set up the food and drinks table.

steps.headline: Greet guests as they arrive.
steps.description: Stand at the door and say “Hello” or “Welcome” to your guests as they arrive for the party. Guide them into the venue and direct them to the food and drinks table. Take your guests’ coats and other items, as needed. If your guests have brought gifts to the party, be sure to direct them to the gifts table.

steps.headline: Surprise the bride when she arrives.
steps.description: Traditionally, bridal showers are a surprise for the bride. You may set up an elaborate surprise where the guests pop out and yell “surprise” as the bride arrives at the venue. Or you may simply have the bride arrive a few minutes later than everyone else and surprise her that way. Another option is to blindfold the bride and have her enter the venue. Then, remove the blindfold and surprise her with a drink as well as the company of her closest friends. Ivy has over 10 years of experience consulting, planning and coordinating weddings around the globe. She has also created a DIY online wedding planning course for couples, called "Plan Your Wedding Like A Pro." She currently resides in Greece where she continues to work with a worldwide network of planners and wedding professionals. Ivy Summer			Certified Wedding & Event Planner				Delegate the task of planning the party to someone other than the bride. Traditionally, the bride does not plan her own pre-wedding parties, like the bridal shower and bachelorette party. However, some brides who enjoy do-it-yourself projects might decide to plan the parties herself, which is also okay.

steps.headline: Make sure the food and drinks do not run low.
steps.description: Keep an eye on the food and drinks table to ensure they do not run out. Have back up food and drinks on hand so your guests are never without something to sip or nibble on during the party.
